content.title: CHALLENGES FOR UNIVERSAL ENERGY ACCESS
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3

content.text: Lesson 3 Overview

Accelerating universal energy access requires identifying key barriers and developing targeted strategies that address the unique needs of different population segments, particularly the most vulnerable. This lesson explores the complex challenges obstructing equitable access to sustainable energy. It highlights critical issues in infrastructure and capacity, the uneven distribution of investments, and the need for comprehensive measurement approaches.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy affordability
concepts.body: Energy affordability refers to the ability of individuals or households to pay for the energy they need without compromising their basic living standards or financial stability.

concepts.title: financial de-risking strategies
concepts.body: Financial de-risking strategies are methods used by organizations to reduce financial risks associated with investments or projects, often by diversifying funding sources, securing insurance, or implementing risk management practices.

content.text: QUESTION FOR REFLECTION

What are the primary barriers in your country or region that hinder universal energy access? What systemic issues underlie these barriers to energy access? How do these barriers interact and compound the challenge of achieving universal energy access?

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Insufficient Energy Infrastructure and Supply Disruptions

content.text: Part 1 Overview

In many regions, the lack of robust national energy infrastructure and reliable supply chains constrains access to electricity, clean cooking fuels, and heating and cooling solutions. Part of the issue is that existing infrastructure is often outdated and in urgent need of modernization, which limits its capacity to support growing energy demands or integrate cleaner, decentralized technologies. This is particularly true for rural and low-income communities, especially when additional layers of vulnerability are considered. Such limitations present a major barrier to extending energy access to underserved populations. This, and other challenges are outlined in this section.

Insufficient energy infrastructure refers to energy systems that lack the capacity, connectivity, and resilience needed to meet current and future energy demands. This includes underdeveloped or outdated infrastructure for generation, transmission, and distribution, which collectively form the backbone of any functional energy system. As defined by the World Economic Forum (WEF., 2024), infrastructure must be “fit-for-purpose, future-ready, and aligned with decarbonization goals”, a standard that many systems in developing and fragile contexts still fall short of. These shortcomings restrict energy services which has more striking consequences in remote areas and fragile contexts. The high costs and complexities associated with extending infrastructure often leave these regions without reliable access to electricity or fuels for cooking, heating, and cooling. Regular maintenance of existing infrastructure is frequently overlooked due to funding constraints or logistical challenges. Aging and poorly maintained equipment increase the risk of energy outages, especially in low-income or remote areas where resources for repairs are scarce. Moreover, there is often a shortage of skilled local workers who can maintain this infrastructure to quality standards. This lack of expertise compromises both safety and the longevity of energy services. Insufficient generation capacity exacerbates these issues. In many electricity networks, generation capacity fails to meet demand, leading to frequent interruptions in supply, such as blackouts. This reduces resilience against external shocks. Additionally, many regions, including Small Island Developing States (SIDS), rely heavily on imported fuels. This reliance makes them particularly vulnerable to fluctuations in global energy markets. Energy supply chain disruptions pose another significant barrier to vulnerable populations. In many developing countries, issues such as pipeline damage, geopolitical tensions, price fluctuations, and even climate events disrupt energy source operations. These disruptions lead to underutilization of available resources and jeopardizing the secure electricity supply.

The interplay of unstable fuel provisioning and high costs intensifies the struggle for vulnerable populations to achieve reliable energy access. Uncertainties in fuel provisioning place a stranglehold on energy demands, exacerbating issues of supply reliability and perpetuating the energy access gap. As a result, individuals in these communities face ongoing difficulties in securing dependable electricity, clean cooking solutions, and climate-resilient heating and cooling.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Skewed and Insufficient Investments

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Access to adequate and evenly distributed investments is critical to achieving universal energy access, yet current funding falls short, particularly in vulnerable regions. This section presents key investment challenges, including uneven financial flows, lack of support for off-grid and clean cooking solutions, and the need for de-risking strategies to attract private capital.

Global financial flows to support clean energy access in developing countries rebounded in 2022, reaching USD 15.4 billion. Most of this recovery came from investments in Latin America and the Caribbean. However, this recovery did not reverse a long-term decline, with least-developed countries (LDCs), landlocked developing countries (LLDCs), and small island developing states (SIDS) facing significant gaps that risk delaying progress toward universal energy access (IEA et al., 2024). Investment remains highly concentrated, with 80% of commitments going to just 25 countries in 2022. Between 2010 and 2022, LLDCs attracted more finance than LDCs. Flows to SIDS reflect the most even distribution relative to their population, with 80 percent of investments going to countries in which 86 percent of the population lives. To complement this data, turn to Module 4, Chapter 1, Lesson 2 to dive deeper into global energy investment landscape.

This uneven distribution of investment highlights the need for policymakers to address barriers that hold back investment in many countries, such as: Higher interest rates: Developing countries often face borrowing costs that are 2–3 times higher than in high-income countries, which slows down long-term renewable energy investments. High cost of capital: Limited access to affordable financing and underdeveloped financial markets raise the cost of capital, making projects less bankable. Currency and exchange rate risks: Local revenues in unstable currencies and debt in foreign currency create financial uncertainty for investors Political and regulatory risk: Frequent policy shifts, lack of transparency, or risk of expropriation discourage foreign direct investment. Unclear policy frameworks: Inconsistent or poorly enforced energy regulations reduce investor confidence and may increase project development risks. Challenges to renewable energy investments and solutions to surmount them will be further developed in module 4.
Lack of funding for off-grid solutions

Another major hurdle to achieving universal access to electricity is a lack of funding for off-grid, sustainable energy solutions that can extend electricity to last-mile communities. Achieving universal electricity access requires about USD 170 billion in investments to connect 826 million people by 2030. This is possible only by deploying a combination of grid, mini-grid, and stand-alone off-grid solutions that leverage the faster deployment of distributed renewables to meet current levels of demand quickly (IEA et al., 2024).
Lack of funding for clean cooking solutions

Today, clean cooking investments are around USD 2.5 billion annually, substantially lower than the required to deliver on broader climate and energy objectives. To approach universal access to clean cooking solutions, USD 8 billion is needed annually between now and 2030 – requiring a cumulative investment of around USD 60 billion. Africa makes up around half of these investment needs, almost USD 4 billion annually. Further advancement of innovative funding mechanisms, public-private partnerships, and targeted subsidies can increase investment and adoption of clean cooking solutions (IEA, 2024).
Need to de-risk for commercial capital

While public financing will continue to play a key role, there is a need to deploy commercial capital to bridge the investment gap and realize universal access to electricity, particularly in remote rural areas. These areas are often perceived as too risky by private investors, highlighting the necessity for innovative financial solutions and strategic government action. This investment gap is a critical barrier to achieving climate goals and underscores the need for increased support and innovative financing mechanisms to de-risk energy transition investments in the most vulnerable regions.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Policy, Governance and Institutional Barriers to Energy Access

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Achieving universal energy access is more than a technical or financial challenge, it is also deeply influenced by the policy, governance, and institutional environment in which energy systems operate. In many developing countries, weak policies, regulatory gaps, and institutional limitations can undermine electrification efforts, deter investment, and leave millions without reliable energy. This section explores four major barriers that fall under this category: weak policy frameworks, poor regulatory environments, lack of institutional capacity, and non-cost reflective tariffs.
Weak Policy Frameworks: Lack of Coherent National Energy Strategy Aligned with Universal Access Goals

One important barrier to expanding energy access is the absence of a coherent, long-term national energy strategy aligned with universal access objectives. In many low- and middle-income countries, energy planning tends to be fragmented across different ministries or agencies, Lacking internal coordination and integration with broader development goals. This makes it difficult to prioritize energy access for marginalized populations, especially in rural areas. Countries that lack clear and consistent policy roadmaps are less able to attract investment or implement large-scale electrification programs, thus slowing progress toward Sustainable Development Goal 7. Without a strategic vision that sets clear targets and mechanisms for implementation, efforts to expand access may remain underfunded.
Poor Regulatory Environment: Inconsistent Policies and Inefficiencies Can Slow Down Electrification

Inconsistent policies, unclear licensing procedures, and delays in project approvals can create uncertainty and discourage investors and energy planners from engaging in energy access projects. In some cases, regulatory inefficiencies lead to long delays in grid connection for off-grid or mini-grid developers, or sudden changes in feed-in tariffs that disrupt project viability. These regulatory inconsistencies can be particularly harmful in fragile or transitioning political contexts as they can erode trust in public institutions. Stable, transparent, and well-enforced regulations are essential to scale up energy access and ensure equitable delivery.
Lack of Institutional Capacity: Limited Expertise and Coordination of Energy Sector Planners

Institutional capacity refers to the ability of government agencies, utilities, and energy planners to effectively design, implement, and monitor energy access policies. In many developing countries, this capacity is limited by human resource shortages, lack of technical expertise, and weak coordination between stakeholders. For instance, in Tanzania, research overlapping mandates and poor communication among local government institutions slowed down efforts to improve energy access and efficiency in rural areas (Chisom., 2021). Without strong institutions able to coordinate across sectors, set performance targets, and engage communities for inclusive energy access, electrification efforts remain unfulfilled. Capacity-building, both at the central and local government levels, is critical to ensure that energy planning and delivery systems are efficient and inclusive.
Non-Cost Reflective Tariffs

Electricity pricing is another key area where policy and governance barriers are present. In many countries, electricity tariffs are set below cost-recovery levels— which means that the price consumers pay for electricity is less than the actual cost of producing, transmitting, and distributing it. This is often done as a means to protect low-income consumers, but can lead to financial losses for utilities, and discourage private investment. A recent study found that poorly targeted subsidies and underpriced electricity were contributors to utility debt and limited the ability of energy providers to expand services (Ali & Li., 2024). More targeted subsidies or tiered pricing models could help improve affordability, thus preserving inclusive energy access for lower-income households who need it the most, without distorting financial viability.

Overall, addressing these policy, regulatory, and institutional barriers requires inclusive governance approaches that reflect the needs of marginalized and underserved populations. This means involving local communities in planning processes, ensuring transparency in regulatory decisions, and building trust through accountable institutions.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 4
content.title: Part 4: Energy Affordability of Vulnerable Communities

content.text: Part 4 Overview

Achieving universal energy access is inseparable from the question of affordability, recognizing that income disparities and the purchasing power of diverse communities significantly impact the feasibility of energy services. This section briefly outlines three major dimensions of affordability to take into consideration in projects addressing energy access
Upfront costs of energy infrastructure

The initial investment required for establishing energy infrastructure can present a significant hurdle to impoverished states and marginalized communities. The cost of installing solar panels, building power grids, or implementing clean cooking solutions can be prohibitively high - often because the cost of capital is so steep (Papthanasiou, 2022).
2. Ongoing operational expenses

Beyond the initial setup, ongoing operational expenses can further strain the affordability of energy access. The maintenance, fuel, and service costs associated with energy technologies contribute to the financial burden faced by communities, especially when the cost of energy itself is often not only high but also marked by volatility which is particularly challenging for the poorest to deal with.
Economic capacity of individuals and communities

The ongoing financial commitments associated with operational costs and recurrent consumption may deter the adoption of cleaner and more sustainable energy solutions, particularly in communities with limited disposable income. The burden of disproportionately high energy costs can exacerbate existing inequalities, forcing individuals to allocate a substantial portion of their income to meet basic energy needs, leaving them with fewer resources for other essential necessities.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 3 | Part 5
content.title: Part 5: Conundrums in Measuring Inclusive and Sustainable Energy Access

content.text: Part 5 Overview

Globally, energy access assessments tend to focus primarily on the availability of electricity, while other critical dimensions, such as affordability, reliability, and safety, face significant measurement challenges. This section explores the complexities involved in accurately gauging access to inclusive and sustainable energy services.

Global estimations predominantly revolve around the availability aspect of electricity access. This is primarily because monitoring the other facets of access mentioned earlier presents additional challenges. In terms of affordability, the concept of “Fuel Poverty” offers valuable insights into monitoring households' energy expenditures relative to their total income, as presented in chapter 1. However, cultural, climatic, and regional differences may impact the cost of energy services and the income required to afford them, making it challenging to establish universal benchmarks for fuel poverty. Thus, while monitoring households' energy expenditures relative to their total income offers valuable insights into affordability, there is no comprehensive fuel poverty tracking index on a global scale. Most of the existing fuel poverty indexes are assessed at the national level, with limited efforts to apply them regionally. Even so, the metrics used to quantify fuel poverty can vary across regions, and a one-size-fits-all approach may not capture the nuanced socio-economic dynamics that influence energy affordability. Another conundrum is that focusing solely on affordability may overlook other dimensions of sustainable energy access, such as reliability, safety, and environmental sustainability. Measuring access to heating and cooling solutions introduces further complexities due to the diverse technologies and fuels involved, as well as varying climatic needs, as shown in Lesson 2.2.

The absence of comprehensive cross-sectional data encompassing socioeconomic factors, including gender dynamics, poses challenges for devising equitable and inclusive energy access strategies. Without disaggregated data, it becomes difficult to identify and address the specific needs and barriers faced by marginalized groups. Additionally, a lack of understanding on consumer preferences, in developing countries- meaning what technologies or tools are most adapted to cultural and societal habits- can hinder the design of socially acceptable energy access solutions. Given that consumer preferences may vary depending on geographic location and culture, obtaining such data is important. In order to address the specific needs and barriers faced by marginal groups, it's important to obtain broad socio-economic data that is disaggregated - e.g., by gender, income level, etc. A comprehensive approach to measuring energy access should incorporate multidimensional factors to ensure a holistic understanding of the challenges faced by communities in securing clean and sustainable energy services.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Limited infrastructure, unreliable supply chains, lack of political will, regulatory barriers, and insufficient local capacity in vulnerable regions create persistent barriers to universal energy access, leaving underserved communities without stable access to electricity, clean cooking fuels, and climate-adapted heating and cooling solutions.

Inadequate and unevenly distributed investments limit progress toward universal energy access, particularly in vulnerable regions. Achieving SDG7 requires increased financing for decentralized solutions and clean cooking, alongside innovative mechanisms to attract private capital.

Affordability is a key barrier to universal energy access, as high upfront costs, ongoing operational expenses, and limited economic capacity among vulnerable communities make sustainable energy solutions inaccessible for many, deepening existing inequalities.

A comprehensive approach to assess energy access must account for multiple dimensions, including affordability, reliability, and socio-economic factors, to effectively address the diverse challenges faced by marginalized communities in securing clean and sustainable energy services.
